repnme.cdata!:
India - Rajasthan District Primary
            Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rajasthan District Primary Education
            Project for India rated as follows: the outcome was
            unsatisfactory, the sustainability was likely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both satisfactory. Lessons
            learned from the project: The need for a reliable monitoring
            and evaluation system for understanding project impact. The
            limited availability and questionable reliability of
            information on the project's development objectives did
            constrain effective implementation. Implementation and
            supervision performances could be greatly impacted by the
            stability of key staff. As presented in the report, the
            frequent change of key staff such as the State Project
            Director has prevented the project from being smoothly
            implemented and has even contributed to undermining the
            impact of various actions. Teacher availability and
            productivity are key ingredients for achieving overall
            program outcomes. Greater accountability in service delivery
            across institutional levels will be important for
            accelerating the pace towards education outcomes. Careful
            assessment of the motivation of key stakeholders and
            realistically planning the capacity building required if
            decentralization of education management is to be
            implemented. Private school development, a new feature that
            requires greater attention for monitoring both sector's
            performance and policy.

5083838.majtheme: Public sector governance,Rural development,Human development,Social dev/gender/inclusion

repnme.cdata!:
India - Rajasthan District Primary
            Education Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Rajasthan District Primary Education
            Project assists the government of India in building and
            strengthening state, district, and sub-district capacities
            to ensure good quality primary education (five years) for
            all primary-age children, especially those from
            disadvantaged groups. There are three project components.
            The first expands access to primary education by opening new
            schools, constructing additional classrooms, and repairing
            existing classrooms; positioning para-professionals in
            schools to meet increased enrollment; and strengthening
            child development centers and selectively establishing early
            childhood education centers in villages. The second
            component increases retention and improves learning
            achievement by promoting community awareness and mobilizing
            community involvement; establishing school management
            committees for each school; constructing toilets and
            drinking water facilities; developing instructional material
            for students; instituting continuous in-service training for
            and on-site professional support to teachers; and developing
            targeted interventions for special focus groups. The third
            component improves state and district capacity to manage
            primary education by establishing project offices, and block
            and cluster resource centers; strengthening the state
            educational research and training institute responsible for
            curriculum development and teacher training.
